div.p: um I just wanted to like start this off
with a little like personal story like
lobbying in Chicago is something that I
admittedly know very little about yet
this is the very first Civic app that I
ever worked on it's called Chicago
lobbyist org it was really like kind of
the start to like my journey in doing
this stuff and it was all because this
open data was available and one of the
things that I learned from building this
website is that like you can make
something and you can put a bunch of
stuff on a web page but in this case it
only like led to more questions like
what like so Theodore Bruns well he's a
lobbyist right looks like he's making a
lot of money he does stuff like procure
business like like what does that even
mean right so there's just so much to
know and I feel like so much of it
cannot be or at least has not yet been
captured by anything data that's like
open data right you need people to tell
you what's going on and so we have a
very cool person here Adrian to give us
a little bit of insight into what she
does and sort of lift the veil a little
bit in terms of what goes on when it
comes to policy at City Council so
without further ado Adrian Alexander
so if you had have gone to me on the
website you would have seen that I do
one thing and that's lobby city council
for a one client and that's apps me and
council 31 so we are one of the biggest
labor unions in the state most people
know us right now because of us being
the largest state employee union and
that budget impasse and the contract we
don't have with the governor yet but I
do i do City Council lobbying I lobby
Cook County I also a lot be at the state
level but for tonight's purposes I'm
going to focus on City Council the
easiest way to explain what I do is I
look at budgets I look at legislation
that comes out I look at what the impact
on our members is going to be I talk to
alderman or state reps whoever about the
impact on our members and then when
they're great with us I hope that they
and help that they get reelected and
when they're not sometimes we support
candidates against them and I help
coordinate our members against them so
it's kind of a really three-pronged
strategy on what I do and I say that
because not all lobbyists do all those
things and because I think it's
particularly important for the work that
I do that I have my hands in all of
those pots so when people ask me about
being a lobbyist because often they're
surprised when I tell them that's what I
do the question that I get asked the
most is well what's your biggest win or
what's the most important piece of
legislation that you've passed and until
this year I didn't really have an answer
because we play a lot of defense that
asked me and but this year we had a big
one at the City Council we after three
years passed an ordinance dealing with
privatization and it started out as the
privatization transparency and
accountability ordinance during the two
thousand eleven budget the mayor moved
to privatize water billing department
and we represented those people is about
40 folks and it was built into the
budget so it got a lot of aldermen kind
of upset it was supposed to save a
hundred thousand dollars there was 40
people who live in the city that we're
getting laid off mostly black South
siders so the aldermen in their wards
you know our members are calling their
alderman to talk about it and alderman
Sawyer introduced the PTA Oh ordinance
um to to try and do something about
creating a process so if the mayor
wanted to privatize something there
would be a council city council would be
involved for assets like the parking
meter feel that most everyone is
familiar with there is a process in
place that was set up by the state
actually that required City Council
passage which is why you know there was
the big uproar that only a few aldermen
voted against it that was not the case
for services and we had a number of
services privatized where we represented
members so we worked with alderman
Sawyer to get this legislation
introduced when it was introduced we had
27 co-sponsors on it um and it was
happened right with in with the budget
process so I called my mom afterwards I
was so excited this was I was like a
year into the job City Council was still
new and fun to me uh-huh and so I call
my mom like oh my gosh I can't believe
it we got the majority of council to
sign on to this privatization ordinance
this is great this is like you know me
getting about 25 was like the thing you
need to hit the number you need to hit
to make things happen majority of
council supports it so of course it's
going to pass so it took three years to
get there um and important is what
happens in the middle so after we got
that the 27 signed on it got kicked to
rules
um and sat for a while we did a lot of
press work we had a broad coalition not
just of other unions but of community
organizations we just like a really
broad coalition I think we had 36
organizations that we worked with namely
the better Government Association got on
board with it and we actually had the
union league club support which you know
when you're talking we were working also
with a DC organization that does work on
like oh great you got the union league
club you know another union organization
I'm like no like there's a big get for
us they even hosted they hosted a press
conference it was a big deal that they
were taking a position on a policy
policy initiative at the city and we had
a pretty diverse group of aldermen on
our side too so so we had some good
spokespeople for the issue is it's
really a quite boring process it's
completely process oriented legislation
that just sets up review after a year
after after the privatization has gone
through you have to meet a certain
threshold things like that there are
really important to us and generally
have you know people care about
privatization in Chicago mostly because
of the parking meter deal so on that in
that sense it was important to people
but it didn't have quite the
touchy-feely very concrete outcomes like
a housing ordinance what so we had to do
a lot of press we actually had a gorilla
sticker campaign on the parking meters
to talk about the ordinance it was hard
to get pressed to stay focused on it
because you know nothing was happening
it was stuck in rules for years and so
they're like well if nothing's happening
there's nothing to talk about and we're
not really going to write stories about
nothing happening for
so we were kind of in limbo for a while
but we were constantly trying to
organize our members and organize
different constituencies around it put
pressure on alderman to go talks in the
mayor to go talk to the chairman of
rules to get some movement on it so it
it took a lot of both like lobbying on
my part but that wouldn't have done it
alone it's a the press it took the
grassroots work and finally we got to a
point it also took an election I think
is fair to say we finally got to the
point where the administration was
willing to sit down with us we
negotiated a deal in in November we in
November we passed the legislation
overwhelmingly so that was like my first
win at City Council and it just kind of
gives you a sense of eight on a policy
level at City Hall it can take a long
time if you're if you're not initially
it's not something that's supported by
the administration someone asked me on
Twitter like about the changing dynamic
between City Council between the council
and the administration and I think it's
important to realize a lot of city
councilmen a lot of aldermen are most of
the calls that they get are not about
policy right like the overwhelming
majority of the calls that alderman get
are about tree trimmings alleys trash
you know these very quality of life very
specific to their award issues those are
the things that drive most voters I mean
even me in my personal life I've only
called my alderman once and it was about
graffiti and and I mean there really
isn't a personal when you're a lobbyist
and calling alderman so I said you know
hey there's this graffiti has been up
forever it's huge it's a really an
eyesore in a problem because it's gang
graffiti and I know you guys cut the
graffiti
sirs blasters into the 2011 budget and
haven't really recovered but you know I
think this should happen so so the
things that drives the voters are really
kind of critical to what drives the
aldermen and they're not being taught to
buy a lot of people about policy issues
so i think that creates both an
opportunity in that if there's something
that you see and you want done I think
you'll stick out because they're not
there's not a lot of folks talking to
alderman about that and you the aldermen
may be willing to work with you in a way
that might surprise you because there's
just not that many people talking about
that but you should also know that when
you're talking to alderman because most
of them i think is fair to say most of
them their mindset isn't that's not the
primary focus of their job there's a lot
of people on the on the election side
you can be the most citywide focused
alderman really focused on policy but if
you don't take care of the stuff in your
ward you will lose your election and I
mean the first round of automatic races
when I came we supported Fred renal I'll
in the sixth Ward and she had like a
ninety-five percent voting record with
us and I remember we were calling our
members to let them know like hey the
union has endorsed and your ward and
people were saying that's great but I
live on her alley and she doesn't even
keep that clean or that's fine but when
I go up to the office where were denied
her staff has an attitude and we were
drilling hard but it didn't matter
because of that very basic stuff and I
think that our members are pretty
engaged right and usually when we tell
them the union's endorse someone this
person has been is in a fight for their
seat and they have a really good record
with the union that usually means
something but alderman Sawyer was able
to beat her and a runoff just for that
very basic reason
so I say that to say those are the
things that are driving a lot of the
alderman and the stuff that's going on
in the media I think I think it's kind
of started I'd say the two thousand and
this the 2015 alder manic races were so
many more went in to run off then
previously ever had happened I think
made a lot of aldermen pay attention
more realize that they had to be more
responsive maybe it wasn't enough to say
I have the support of the mayor they
also have to have something on their own
to stand for more dramatic lighting it's
because I mentioned the mayor um yeah I
think that that kind of made people pay
attention and like it was interesting
because all of the alderman Sawyer
there's being in the Progressive Caucus
and then and in the Black Caucus I think
before the elections there were a number
of aldermen that we're looking at him
like you know you should be careful
stepping out too far and then there was
kind of a wave of more progressive
alderman that got elected and none of
the Progressive Caucus folks that we're
running for alderman lost so I think him
getting elected black caucus chair kind
of shows how how folks mindsets were
changing a little bit and then when you
add on that on top of that the pressures
from laQuan McDonald video and the alder
manic vote and lack of questioning on
the settlement and the pressure that
they've gotten there I think it's making
them more aware and more concern
realizing that they have to do more at
least be seen as doing more but I don't
think I'm not bought into the idea yet
that there's going to be some kind of
revolution and council so where I'm
there there's going to be a huge change
or a huge backlash for the mayor I just
I just haven't seen it yet
um what I did see last council meeting
was a flurry of introductions
particularly around criminal justice and
I think you know people want to be seen
as doing something it'll be interesting
to see a number of those were sent to
rules it'll be interesting to see what
the follow-up is afterwards and whether
people are going to be grandstanding and
pushing and and trying to negotiate to
get things out of rules or if they're
content with having introduced it and
got it getting a press pop um oh I guess
I should also say I think another factor
and that question of Independence will
be the state's attorneys race and I
think if Anita Alvarez ends up losing
the state's attorneys right that'll be
unkind another thing in that in that
list of things that might shift the
dynamics a little bit um I got asked as
well about money in politics and um I
think I started out saying that I have
one one client I am employed by ask me
so that creates a different dynamic than
if I was a contract lobbyist to contract
lobbyist as I see it I've never been a
contract lobbyist but from my
perspective as a contract lobbyist you
have multiple clients they in your
primary focus is the the relationships
at all costs like no one's going to hire
you if you don't have relationships with
seemingly powerful people for me my
primary focus is my members and making
sure that whatever it is I advance
what's best for my members and having
one client kind of allows me to you know
make that the primary focus the issue
the primary focus and not to say nobody
wants to blow off any relationships but
if there's someone my unions going after
then it I don't really have to pretend
I'm associated with the union I am
Adriene from a Smith period bleh
there's no other that is my identity the
people who know me in politics so for us
the way we determine who gets money or
who doesn't oh and I'm pretty proud of
this because it makes my life easier I
get to have the moral high ground we
have a rubric so every time that I ask
people for their vote on something to
sign on to a letter to show up at a
press conference it goes into my excel
sheet and everyone is asked everyone
gets a yes or no they all get a grade
essentially and if you're at a certain
level then you get money and there's
like three bands and it's equal that way
so there you know politicians because
they don't often know that we have a
rubric I get a lot of accusations
especially when I first started
particularly in Springfield there's a
lot of accusations like oh well the
union's give more money to white people
or the union's give more money to
Chicago people and it's easy to say no
look we have this rubric everyone who
falls into this gets this that's how
it's done this person got more money
because they had a better score you
didn't because you voted wrong on half
of our stuff so though it makes it easy
to do that's how we do it everybody of
course doesn't do it that way I can talk
about how other folks do their
contributions there's the question of
lobbyists and taking folks out to eat if
they're kind of pulled me up you were
the same that I didn't spend any money
on taking people out I prefer not to
that's the personal preference um I I
mean especially I think it's more the
case in Springfield where you're in
you're out of town people are going to
dinners a lot that's more prevalent
there although I no contract lobbyist do
a lot more here that's also reflected on
on the on the site but for me it's like
there's no point in buying someone
lunch at City Hall when we can sit in
your office and talk there's no need and
for me I think kind of the stuff that
asks me is asking in particular it's
mostly budget focused and kind of hard
ask you know we want you to step out in
a press conference and say the mayor's
holding on to our our privatization bill
and it should get out rules that's a
harder ask that buying a dinner isn't
going to get you so so why I mean I know
and our money that we give from our pack
is members out of members paychecks so
it makes me feel more responsible like I
need to be responsible with it I would
hate to like be like giving dinner here
dinner here and you know then the next
day people are voting against us on all
the big issues because they were happy
to go to dinner for free but not willing
to step out on a vote because our
members look at that stuff too I mean
it's all available and and so we get
dinged all the time you guys just gave
this person $5,000 and then they did
that as this it should translate but it
doesn't so so it's easier for me I mean
sometimes we do like we take the Black
Caucus out for dinner and Springfield to

card just a principal and then Steve
